PostValue.explanation: This is a practical, operational announcement about a targeted donor funding circle for farmed-animal interventions. It’s not foundational to EA theory, but it’s moderately important within the animal advocacy / EA funding ecosystem because it can direct substantial, concentrated resources to high-leverage projects (especially early-stage groups) and reduce vetting inefficiencies. For the general public it’s low-impact — useful for specific NGOs and donors but not consequential for broad societal decisions.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Missing clarity on selection process and impact criteria — The post doesn’t explain how applications will be evaluated or how donor preferences are aggregated into funding decisions. This is a major omission for applicants and potential donors. Actionable fixes: briefly describe the decision process (who votes, weighting between donor preferences vs. expert review), publish the evaluation rubric/scoring criteria (e.g., expected metrics for “measurable impact”, scalability threshold), and add an estimated timeline for decisions and feedback to applicants.

2) No details on grant sizes, terms, reporting, or geographic/legal scope — Applicants and donors need concrete expectations (typical award size, multi-year vs one-off, reporting/monitoring requirements, whether overheads are allowed, geographic focus or country restrictions). Actionable fixes: include a short sentence specifying typical grant range (or min/max), grant duration, basic reporting expectations, and any geographic or legal constraints; if amounts vary by donor, state that and give examples from round 1.

3) Lack of transparency about past results and governance/conflicts — You say 11 groups were funded from ~150 applicants but provide no info on what those grants achieved or who makes final calls. That weakens trust and donor uptake. Actionable fixes: add 1–2 concrete examples of funded projects and any measurable outcomes (or link to a short results summary), and state who is on the decision-making body or how conflicts of interest are handled (e.g., donor anonymity, recusal rules).
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback identifies real, useful omissions that would aid both applicants and potential donors (selection criteria/process, grant size/terms, reporting, past results and governance). Those additions are actionable and wouldn't need much extra space in the announcement. However, this is an announcement post that links to a full RFP—many of these details may already live there—so their absence from the short post is not a major blunder. Implementing a brief summary of the evaluation process, typical award sizes/terms, and a short note on governance/past grantees (or a link to that info) would substantially improve clarity without bloating the post.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: No identifiable presence in EA/rationalist forums, publications, or speaker lists and no notable coverage in academic or mainstream media. Likely a pseudonymous/social account with no public prominence.

PostClarity.explanation: Overall clear and well-structured: title, deadline, contact, eligibility, and funded/not-funded areas are easy to find and understand, and useful links are provided. Minor weaknesses: a few formatting artifacts and slightly awkward phrasing (the aquatic-circle redirection could be clearer), and some practical details are missing (typical grant sizes, decision timeline, selection process), which would help applicants but don’t prevent comprehension.

PostNovelty.explanation: This is primarily an administrative announcement of a second-round grantmaking opportunity — common within EA and philanthropy. The basic concept (a donor funding circle for farmed-animal advocacy, with eligibility criteria and targeted focus areas) is familiar to EA Forum readers and the wider public. The only mildly uncommon elements are the specific priorities (preference for very early-stage/smaller orgs, openness to wild-animal and genetic/pain research, and coordination with an aquatic-animal circle), but these are incremental operational choices rather than novel ideas.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: The post is clear, well-structured and internally consistent: it states the circle is running a second round, lists eligibility, past focus areas, and what will/won't be funded, and explains who to contact. That makes the argument (apply/join) logically straightforward. However, it offers little empirical evidence that the circle produces high-impact outcomes: beyond reporting ~150 applicants and 11 groups funded last round there is no data on grant outcomes, metrics used for selection, impact per dollar, monitoring or follow-up, or donor experiences. Claims that the circle will reduce vetting inefficiencies and expose donors to high-impact opportunities are plausible but unsupported. Overall, the announcement is fit for purpose as a call for applications/donors but provides weak evidence for the effectiveness or comparative advantage of this funding model.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most major empirical claims in the post are well-supported by public sources: the Strategic Animal Funding Circle (SAFC) exists, has a website and an EA Forum RFP post, the Round 2 EA Forum announcement (Feb 17, 2025) and the SAFC website show the eligibility criteria, donor-contact email (jozden@mobius.life), and the scope/preferences listed. The SAFC “results” post confirms that the circle funded multiple organisations (the July 2025 results post lists 16 organisations and ≈$900k across the first two rounds) and enumerates the kinds of areas funded that match the Round 2 post. The redirect of aquatic-animal applications to the Farmed Animal Funders / Aquatic Animal Funding Circle is also documented. The only slightly uncertain claim is the precise internal metrics reported in the Round 2 post (“approx. 150 applicants last round” and “funded 11 groups”): public posts confirm multiple grantees and applicant rounds but I could not find an independent public breakdown that directly corroborates the exact “~150 applicants” figure or the specific “11 groups” count for that single prior round (the public results post aggregates two rounds → 16 organisations). Overall: most claims verified; a couple of internal counts appear to be author-reported and not independently published elsewhere.
sources: EA Forum — "Strategic Animal Funding Circle - Round 2 is now live!" (JamesÖz), Feb 17, 2025 — https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/HntPPrXyLLTJjfpiq/strategic-animal-funding-circle-round-2-is-now-live

SAFC website — Strategic Animal Funding Circle (animalfundingcircle.com) — content showing eligibility, donor contribution thresholds, and contact email jozden@mobius.life — https://www.animalfundingcircle.com/

EA Forum — "Strategic Animals Funding Circle - Results from first two rounds" (Martijn Klop, Joey, JamesÖz), Jul 21, 2025 — shows funded organisations and total ~$900k across 16 organisations — https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/fRQejQGJsKx33ud8u/strategic-animals-funding-circle-results-from-first-two
Farmed Animal Funders — Aquatic Animal Funding Circle page (explains aquatic funding circle and application channel) — https://farmedanimalfunders.org/aquatic-animal-funding-circle
SAFC RFP (Round 2, Feb 2025) — Google Doc referenced in the post — https://docs.google.com/document/d/1HH-P4-m24IhjFEhx_hxTdETVDcqZ_KoLgITepSuj3MY/edit?usp=sharing
